docs.lead_paragraph: People who order prescription drugs via the Internet may be paying more than they would at a drugstore and taking chances with their health, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School report. The researchers examined 46 Web sites that sold prescription drugs directly to the public. Their study will be published in December in the journal Annals of Internal Medicine, but it was released last month and made available on the Internet at www.acponline.org because the journal's editor thought the public should have the information right away.

headline.main: Drug Buying On the Web? Be Careful, Study Says

docs.lead_paragraph: The first pneumonia vaccine designed for infants has been tested in a major study and appears to sharply reduce severe cases of the disease, researchers said last week. The vaccine, which will be considered soon for approval in the United States, is intended to protect children from illnesses caused by the pneumococcus bacteria.

headline.main: Infant Pneumonia Shots Pass Early Test

docs.abstract: First pneumonia vaccine designed for infants is tested in major study and appears to sharply reduce severe cases of disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a fairly typical issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association: six articles on traumatic brain injury, another on whether children should have their tonsils and adenoids taken out, an editorial titled ''Otitis Media: The Pharyngeal Connection.'' And then there was the cover illustration. It showed no patients with bandaged heads, no dazed athletes, no tonsils, no adenoids. Instead, a page from a 15th-century encyclopedia displayed its stately Latin, floral illuminations in lapis lazuli and gold spilling down the margin.

headline.main: Uncommon Denominator of Art and Medicine

docs.abstract: Dr M Therese Southgate, physician and senior editor of Journal of American Medical Assn, has chosen JAMA's cover art for last 25 years and written page-long essay for each weekly issue about her selection; JAMA's covers invariably feature fine art, and the art often has nothing to do with medicine; she declares that she is trying to show that 'everything is related: art, medicine, life'; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who works in a hospital knows that the role of nurses goes far beyond their traditional duties: insuring patient comfort, monitoring vital signs, dispensing medicine. Last year, when I was an intern, I took care of a patient in his 40's with terminal leukemia whose condition had so deteriorated that his family had approved a morphine drip.

headline.main: Taking Care of Nurses, Before It's Too Late

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar Essay holds that nurses provide essential psychological and emotional support to patients, as well as medical care; says hospitals must take care of nurses, attending to their financial needs, and other practical concerns of their lives (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wig makers, tremble! Purveyors of hair restorer, whether F.D.A.-approved or purest snake-oil, brush up on bankruptcy law! Messrs. Michael Milken, Ted Danson, Marv Albert and all hairpiece wearers; Governor Ventura and the proudly bald, and all those about to become so -- listen carefully, for a sudden ray of hope is playing upon all your shining pates! The new herald of hirsuteness is no mere cream or chemical but a gene with the strange and potent name of Sonic hedgehog. Known to gene jockeys by its acronym SHH, it is not unworthy of silent awe. SHH is a master sculptor of the human body. In the growing embryo it divides the brain into segments. Too little SHH can cause cyclopia, an undivided brain with a single central eye, a condition named after the terrible cyclops who imprisoned Odysseus and devoured his men.

headline.main: Of Mice, Men and a Gene That Jump-Starts Follicles

docs.abstract: Gene therapists at Weill Medical College of Cornell University force resting hair follicles of mice into their growth phase by exposing cells to activity of Sonic hedgehog gene; although no experiments have yet been done in people, there seems a reasonable chance that Sonic hedgehog, or related genes, might be used to treat human baldness; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is well known that nearly half of all marriages end in divorce. With that in mind, a psychology professor from Wright State University surveyed husbands and wives once a year over the first decade of their marriages to observe how marital quality changes over time. The researcher, Dr. Larry A. Kurdek, found that couples often began their unions with high levels of marital quality, but that it appeared to decrease twice: once rather steeply over the first four years and again after about seven. (The pattern of change was the same for both husbands and wives.) He also reported that couples with children experienced the steepest declines.

headline.main: Study Finds a 7-Year Itch, and a 4-Year One

docs.abstract: Dr Larry A Kurdek, psychology professor, surveys married couples once a year over first decade of their marriages to observe how marital quality changes over time; finds that couples often begin their unions with high levels of marital quality, but that it appears to decrease twice: once rather steeply over first four years, and again after about seven; he also reports that couples with children experience steepest declines (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As doctors and parents know, it often takes more than one course of the pink stuff to cure a childhood ear infection, because the offending bacteria are becoming resistant to standard antibiotic treatments. But new research suggests just how widespread the problem is. More than a third of children with middle-ear infections may now harbor drug-resistant bacteria, according to Dr. Stan Block, president of Kentucky Pediatric Research in Bardstown. Dr. Block based this estimate on a study he and colleagues conducted from 1989 to 1998 in which they took bacteria samples from 700 children with recurrent middle-ear infections. During that period the number of children with resistant bacteria increased by nearly 30 percent, according to the study, which was presented last month at a conference on antimicrobial drugs.

headline.main: Ear Infections Getting Tougher to Treat

docs.abstract: New research finds that it is getting harder to treat ear infections in children because many of them now harbor drug-resistant bacteria (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Single mothers have been stereotyped, politicized and vilified, but a new Cornell study of young children offers them some comforting news: in and of itself, single parenthood seems to have no effect on how a child does in school. In a national, multi-ethnic study, researchers tested 1,700 6- and 7-year-olds in vocabulary, reading and math, and for behavior problems. They then correlated those scores with several characteristics, including family structure, family income and parents' educational level and general abilities as measured by a standardized test.

headline.main: For Single Parents, One Less Worry

docs.abstract: Cornell University study finds that single parenthood, in and of itself, seems to have no effect on how child does in school (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A ''silent stroke'' has none of the warning signs of a larger stroke: severe headaches, dizziness, loss of motor skills. Often victims do not realize they have had strokes. As small blood vessels in the brain become blocked or ruptured, victims may experience memory loss, difficulty with concentration or trouble walking. Now researchers say they have found a link between silent strokes and depression. In a study of 3,660 people over 50 that appears in this month's issue of the journal Stroke, the scientists found that having the brain lesions associated with silent stroke increases a patient's risk of having significant symptoms of depression by 40 percent.
docs.abstract: Researchers say they have found link between silent strokes and depression; find that having brain lesions associated with silent stroke increases patient's risk of having significant symptoms of depression by 40 percent (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Do you think your toddler or preschooler is living on thin air? Has mealtime become a battle of wills? How many of these admonitions are familiar to you? ''Finish your dinner! The children in [unfortunate country] are starving.''

headline.main: When Good Intentions Backfire and Create Food Aversions

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns parent that trying to get their children to eat can sometimes backfire and create food aversions; recommends Feeding Your Child for Lifelong Health, book by Dr Susan B Roberts, Dr Melvin B Heyman and Lisa Tracy, which offers strategies that mesh with children's changing stages and foster interest in foods that are essence of good nutrition (M)
